monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: The Sun Temple at Konark was commissioned by King Narasimhadeva I of the Eastern Ganga Dynasty to honor the Sun God, Surya.
The temple's construction was carried out by an army of skilled architects and artisans, symbolizing the king’s devotion and power.

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: The Sun Temple is located in Konark, Odisha, India, near the coastline of the Bay of Bengal, which adds to its striking scenic beauty.
It stands about 35 kilometers from Puri, another famous pilgrimage site, making Konark a significant cultural and religious destination in eastern India.

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: The temple was constructed in the 13th century, with its construction beginning around 1243 AD and completed in 1255 AD.
It was built during the reign of Narasimhadeva I, reflecting the architectural brilliance and cultural richness of the Eastern Ganga Dynasty.

monumentInformation.title: How Is It Protected By
details: The Sun Temple is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, recognized for its unique architectural style and historical significance.
It is protected and maintained by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which ensures its preservation and conservation.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: The Sun Temple was built to worship the Sun God, Surya, and is designed as a massive chariot with intricately carved wheels and horses, symbolizing Surya’s chariot.
The temple also served as a demonstration of the Eastern Ganga Dynasty's power and architectural expertise, making it a monument of both religious and political significance.
